name: Toronto
fun_fact: Fun fact: Toronto was nicknamed 'Hogtown' over 100 years ago due to its booming pork industry, and its signature Peameal Bacon Sandwich at St. Lawrence Market has been made the same way since the 1960s - fried peameal ends on a kaiser with honey mustard!

hero_dishes.name: Peameal Bacon Sandwich
hero_dishes.description: Toronto's official dish - cornmeal-crusted pork loin on kaiser roll with honey mustard
hero_dishes.origin_story: Invented at St. Lawrence Market in the 1960s using butcher's peameal loin ends
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Carousel Bakery at St. Lawrence Market (the original), Paddington's Pump

hero_dishes.name: Chinese Dim Sum
hero_dishes.description: Steamed dumplings, bao buns, and small plates
hero_dishes.origin_story: Toronto has one of North America's largest Chinatowns
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Rol San, dim sum houses in Chinatown and Markham

hero_dishes.name: Jamaican Jerk Chicken
hero_dishes.description: Spicy marinated grilled chicken with Caribbean spices
hero_dishes.origin_story: Large Caribbean community brought authentic jerk culture
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Chris Jerk, Caribbean restaurants across the city

hero_dishes.name: Sushi Pizza
hero_dishes.description: Crispy rice base topped with salmon, tuna, and sushi toppings
hero_dishes.origin_story: Toronto fusion invention combining Japanese and Italian

signature_drinks.name: Caesar Cocktail
signature_drinks.description: Canada's national cocktail - vodka, Clamato, Worcestershire, hot sauce
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Brunch staple, often with elaborate garnishes

food_culture_notes: St. Lawrence Market (since 1803) is the food heart of Toronto
200+ ethnic groups make Toronto one of world's most diverse food cities
Kensington Market for eclectic international food vendors
Distillery District for upscale dining in historic setting
